1_1MwJSNBC1savftEvXQyoHcVLDgThtAPr6T.body:
> [sarasa](#comment_4_1HLFF47LhPMfkv43GJoGCn7ZwXEAZmFHC6): Something to keep in mind is that all of the very popular social media systems have had large sums of cash inserted at various stages along the way. This supported not only coding and development but advertising and manipulating consumer confidence. Remember when Gmail first appeared and people were horrified that a corporation might scan the inbox to collect data (and then return it to you in the form of advertising). Google had a lot of money then. They have even more now.
> Decentralization and marketplace free content is not likely to inspire investors because there is no return on investment except personal gratification. 
> What do you think Linus Torvalds would have said to you if you approached the initial development of Linux in the early years, the way you have ZeroNet in this post?? (hint: Torvalds doesn't mince his words) There were plenty of free and open source ecosystems floating around that time.  What made Linux fly is anyones guess. I'd guess the stars aligned right.
> To me, your post is a slap to the face of the ZeroNet community. I'm sure the ZeroNet developers read this and thought... oh well... back to work.
